awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Beyond CS Principles:Engaging Female High School Students in New Frontiers of Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Building on the foundations set by the AP Computer Science (CS) Principles course, this project seeks to dramatically expand access, especially for high school girls, to the most exciting and emerging frontiers of computing, such as distributed computation, the internet of things (IoT), cybersecurity, and machine learning, as well as other 21st century skills required to productively leverage computational methods and tools in virtually every profession. Creating pathways that stimulate high school learners' interest in advanced topics with the goal of building a diverse, gender-balanced, future-ready workforce is a crucial and impactful imperative addressed in this work. An experienced multi-disciplinary team of researchers, high school teachers, and industry partners will be involved in the design of a new, modular, open-access curriculum called Computer Science Frontiers (CSF) that provides an engaging introduction to these advanced topics in high school (that are currently accessible only to CS majors in college). To address the dire gender disparity in computing, the project will design and research the curriculum to engage female students. Through studying the impact of innovative computing tools and curricular units on learning, attitudes, interests, and collaboration of students (and especially young women), the project will advance discovery and understanding to aid the cause of broadening participation in technology-related careers as well as the future of work at the human-technology frontier. The open access modular design of the curricular materials and the dissemination activities will ensure wide adoption of the products of this research. 

The project leverages NetsBlox, a powerful yet easy-to-use visual programming environment that has been shown to increase engagement and interest in computing. Additionally, NetsBlox supports effective collaboration while facilitating learning of distributed computing, networking, and cybersecurity in informal settings. Early phases of the project will involve design and refinement of curricular modules through co-design workshops with seven participating teachers, summer camps with students, and pilot implementations in Tennessee and North Carolina, leading to full classroom implementations in Year 3 by the high school teachers. Data collected through surveys, student portfolios, teacher interviews, and digital logs from NetsBlox will be analyzed. Research findings will help in understanding if and how advanced computing methods alongside key competencies can be introduced in high school; how pedagogies involving project-based activities around real-world, multidisciplinary problems work to increase female students' interests in computing; and which advanced topics work better than others in terms of difficulty level and engagement.

This project is funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program, which supports projects that build understandings of practices, program elements, contexts and processes contributing to increasing students' knowledge and interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and information and communication technology (ICT) careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Creating pathways that stimulate high school learners’ interest in advanced, exciting topics in computer science with the goal of building a diverse, gender-balanced, future-ready workforce is crucial. To this end,

Beyond CS Principles: Engaging Female High School Students in New Frontiers of Computing is a collaborative effort that brought together Vanderbilt University (PI Dr. Akos Ledeczi), North Carolina State University (Dr. Tiffany Barnes), and Looking Glass Ventures (PI Dr. Shuchi Grover) to create CS Frontiers (CSF)—a new modular curriculum for high school (HS) computer science (CS). Inspired by the AP Computer Science Principles course, CSF seeks to dramatically expand access, especially for high school girls, to the most exciting and emerging frontiers of computing, such as distributed computing, the Internet of Things (IoT), cybersecurity, and artificial intelligence/machine learning (AI/ML). CSF’s modular, open-access curriculum provides an engaging introduction to these advanced CS topics that HS students use and encounter in their daily lives but are accessible only to computing majors in college. CSF also focuses on other crucial 21st-century skills required to productively leverage computational methods and tools in virtually every profession. To address the dire gender disparity in computing, CSF drew on research on strategies to engage female students. The resulting CSF curriculum is project-based with topics drawn from real-world application domains that are engaging for HS students (such as movies, music, social media, and outdoor activity trackers), by addressing socially-relevant applications (such as climate change, health, and cyberbullying,), and by emphasizing collaboration and teamwork.

 

The modules were iteratively developed and refined through teacher feedback from professional development (PD) workshops that were conducted in the summers of 2020-2022. The teachers (N=8) were majority female and from underrepresented groups and high schools in North Carolina, Tennessee, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, and New York,. Each summer, the PD was followed by a summer camp with HS students (total N=109 students). Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, all the summer PD workshops and student camps were conducted online. Multiple camps over several weeks have also been conducted on the DC (Climate Change unit) and Cybersecurity (with Roboscape) modules at the School for Science and Math at Vanderbilt (SSMV) with over 50 students. The Tennessee (TN) Board of Education accepted the proposed CSF course for high schools in TN. We piloted the course in one classroom (with 6 males and 7 females) in a Nashville public high school in the 2022/2023 academic year. During the 2023-2024 academic year, CSF will be taught in two more classes in TN.

 

Primary data sources for the research were teacher and student surveys and interviews during the workshops, summer camps, and classroom implementation. Overall, findings from teacher PD workshops as well as student camps indicated high levels of engagement in and enthusiasm for the CSF curricular activities and topics. Post-intervention surveys suggest that these experiences generated student interest in exploring these ideas further and connections to topics of interest to students, especially girls.

 

The CSF website hosts all the open-access products of the project, including detailed materials for teaching all 4 CSF modules (csfrontiers.org/curriculum), and the NetsBlox.org site has additional information and guidance on the innovative tools built for the CSF project that power the programming in the CSF modules. These include Roboscape Online for adding advanced simulated virtual robotics, and PhoneIoT for accessing personal device sensors and the interactive display. There are also other tools that are being developed, including PyBlox, which lets teachers use the existing CSF curriculum with Python and a virtual machine that enables a more practical, real-world IoT experience for students programming real embedded sensors.

 

The project team actively engaged in several and varied forms of dissemination of CSF modules, research and design, PD, and implementation over the entire 3 year period of the project. PIs have also presented at the NSF ITEST PI meetings. Over 15 papers (including journal articles and a book chapter) were authored. The team presented at multiple research and practitioner conferences (SIGCSE, Koli Calling, RESPECT, ASEE, EAAI, VL/HCC, SnapCon, and CSTA, among others). Free PD workshops for HS teachers over weekends in Winter 2022-2023 resulted in several additional teachers getting trained on the CSF modules. Workshops and webinars (SIGCSE, CSTA, MNCodes Virtual K12 CS Workshops, NC CTE Summit 2023) have also aided wider dissemination of the CSF curricular modules. Multiple technology demonstrations of NetsBlox, PhoneIoT, PyBlox, and Roboscape Online were given to researcher and CS conferences such as IEEE VL/HCC, ACM/IEEE Information Processing in Sensor Networks Conference, ISLS, and SIGCSE. Team members also showcased CSF in several keynote addresses and other presentations to teacher and researcher audiences. 


Last Modified: 08/23/2023
Modified by: Shuchi Grover
